column1: Sedalia is a city located approximately 30 miles (48 km) south of the Missouri River and
column2: as the county seat of Pettis County
column3: Missouri
column4: United States
column5: it is the principal city of the Sedalia Micropolitan Statistical Area. As of the 2010 census
column6: the city had a total population of 21
column7: 387. Sedalia is also the location of the Missouri State Fair and the Scott Joplin Ragtime Festival. U.S. Routes 50 and 65 intersect in the city.

column1: Until the city was incorporated in 1860 as Sedalia
column2: it had existed only "on paper" from November 30
column3: 1857 to October 16
column4: 1860. According to local lore
column5: the town council changed the name from Sedville to Sedalia in part because "towns that end in -ville don't amount to anything." (Lawrence Ditton Sr.).  Here is another account:

column1: In 1856 General Smith bought the land upon which Sedalia now stands
column2: and founded the city.  He named it after his daughter Sarah
column3: familiarly known as "Sed". Smith remarked that he had previously named a flatboat for her elder sister Martha.  He first chose the name Sedville but changed it to Sedalia
column4: following the suggestion of a friend
column5: Josiah Dent
column6: of St. Louis. Dent suggested the change for the sake of euphony.

column1: Indigenous peoples lived along the Missouri River and its tributaries for thousands of years before European contact. Historians believe the entire area around Sedalia was long occupied by the Osage (among historical American Indian tribes). When the land was first settled by European Americans
column2: bands of Shawnee
column3: who had migrated from east of the Mississippi River
column4: lived in the vicinity of Sedalia.The area that became the European-American city of Sedalia was founded by General George Rappeen Smith (1804–1879)
column5: who also founded nearby Smithton
column6: Missouri. He filed plans for the official record on November 30
column8: and gave the area the name Sedville.  The original plat included the land from today's Missouri Pacific Railroad south to Third Street.

column1: The version jointly filed by General Smith and David W. Bouldin on October 16
column3: displayed the city extending from Clay Street to the north and to Smith Street (today's Third Street) in the south
column4: and from Missouri Street in the west to Washington Street in the east; and
column5: although Smith and Bouldin predicted that the city would grow to the north
column6: it grew in a southern direction.

column1: Following a victory for those proposing the "ridge route" for the railway over those advocating the "river route"
column2: the railway reached Sedalia in January 1861. Sedalia's early prosperity was directly related to the railroad industry. Many jobs were associated with men maintaining tracks and operating large and varied machine shops run by both the Missouri Pacific and the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad lines. The Missouri-Kansas & Texas Railroad was widely known as the "KATY
column3: from its K-T" stock exchange code.

column1: Sedalia was an important railhead for the massive Texas cattle drive of 1866. It maintained stockyards to receive cattle from drives and shipping through much of the 19th century.

Chicago slaughterhouses were willing to pay almost any price [for beef]—longhorns were worth three to four dollars each on the Llano Estacado while in Chicago a steer was worth ten times that amount.  It cost about a dollar per head to drive a herd northward to a railroad
column2: and thus with these simple economics
column3: the long drive and the cattle bonanza got its start.

column1: After the KATY reduced its operations in the 20th century
column2: its railroad right-of-way through much of Missouri was converted to a 240-mile multi-use trail. The KATY Trail is used by bikers
column3: walkers and horseback riders. This has been the largest new trail developed in the nation among the late 20th-century federal and state "Rails to Trails" projects.

column1: Sedalia was made a military post early in the war and remained such until its close in 1865. For this reason it was an active theater of operations for military supplies and an objective point for capture by "the boys in gray." Confederate raids into Pettis County
column2: and the offensive and defensive activities of Union troops against them
column3: kept the inhabitants of Sedalia in [a] high state of excitement. The progress of the city was retarded [during that time]. Sentiment in the county was about evenly divided.
Shelby's Confederate cavalry brigade surrounded the Union post of Sedalia. The post commander
column4: Colonel John D. Crawford
column5: fled. Captain Oscar B. Queen of Company M
column6: 7th Cavalry
column8: surrendered the post shortly thereafter.  Missouri State Guard Brigadier-General M. Jeff Thompson subsequently paroled the prisoners of war and moved on

column1: While the Civil War delayed development of the town in some respects
column2: Sedalia was the terminus of the railroad for three years. Once the war was over
column3: many of the thousands of Union soldiers who had been stationed more or less permanently at Sedalia and recognized its potential
column4: made the choice to migrate there from their former homes in other areas. The population grew rapidly.In the late 19th century
column5: Sedalia was well known as a center of vice
column6: especially prostitution
column7: which accompanied its large floating class of railroad workers and commercial travelers. In 1877 the St. Louis Post-Dispatch called Sedalia the "Sodom and Gomorrah of the nineteenth century." Middle-class businessmen made money off illegal prostitution as building owners and lessees; others did business with people in the industry
column11: in town. Residents were reluctant to raise taxes and services were provided from the fines charged to prostitutes.In the 1870s brothels were distributed throughout the city
column13: they became more concentrated above businesses on West Main Street
column14: as the middle class tried to isolate less desirable elements in town. These establishments also employed musicians
column16: contributing to a thriving musical culture. It fostered the development of many artists
column17: including the renowned ragtime composer Scott Joplin.

column1: While the city attracted many commercial travelers and railroad workers
column2: its population of married couples and families also grew. By 1900 its population of more than 15
column3: 000 made it the fifth-largest city in the state. The entrepreneurial middle class created more formal separations between its residential areas and those of working class whites and African Americans.During World War II
column4: the military built Sedalia Glider Base in Johnson County to the west. After the war
column5: this facility was transferred to the Strategic Air Command. It was converted to a bomber base
column6: the Whiteman Air Force Base
column7: named after 2nd Lt. George A. Whiteman
column8: an Army Air Corps pilot who was killed during the 1941 Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. After a massive construction program
column9: the base became the center of 150 ICBM silos and administrative offices. These were decommissioned in the 1990s.

column1: Sedalia is home to the nation's first sheltered workshop
column2: which opened in 1965.

column1: The expansion of the railroad and cattle drives in the late 19th century brought many male laborers to the rough town on the frontier. It sparked the related rise of a notorious "red light district
column2:
with numerous prostitutes who did business with the men in saloons and brothels, which also featured musical entertainments.
As more families settled in the area, they made the culture more stable, creating institutions such as schools and churches. In the late 20th century, structural changes in the railroads meant the loss of many industrial jobs, but the city has held on to a population close to its 1960 peak while developing new bases for the economy. The city is informally known as the Trailer Capital of the Midwest
column3:
due to the high number of trailer manufacturers and dealers in the area.
Residents have emphasized the colorful history of the town for heritage tourism, and identified many significant historic structures for state and national recognition. Good quality retail and craft items are sold in the historic districts and buildings of the city.


=== Registered Historic Places ===
The following Sedalia locations have been listed on the National Register of Historic Places:
Building at 217 West Main Street, former brothel 
G and G Veterinary Hospital
William H. Gentry House
John T. and Lillian Heard House
Harris House
Hotel Bothwell 
C.C. Hubbard High School 
Henry Jones Farmstead
McVey School 
Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railroad Depot 
Missouri/Sedalia Trust Company 
Missouri State Fairgrounds Historic District 
Sedalia Commercial Historic District 
Sedalia Public Library 


== Geography ==
Sedalia is located at 38°42'11 North

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 13.32 square miles (34.50 km2)
column3: of which 13.29 square miles (34.42 km2) is land and 0.03 square miles (0.08 km2) is water.

column1: Sedalia has a typical temperate climate. As with most continental climates
column2: the micropolitan area has four seasons. Springs in Sedalia are noted for their rainy days and variable temperatures. Thunderstorms are common and tornadoes occur during this time of year. Summers are usually hot and humid
column3: with droughts occurring during several summers. Autumns are usually cool and rainy
column4: although several days of warm weather are not uncommon. Winters are generally cold
column5: with snow accumulating several days of the winter season. Although not as common
column6: ice storms occur as well.

column1: The Sedalia Public Library was the first Carnegie Grant awarded in Missouri. The Board of Trustees received word of the $50

column1: The 1948 film Scudda Hoo! Scudda Hay! premiered at Fox Theatres. The premiere was attended by Lon McCallister
column2: Colleen Townsend
column3: Luanne Hogan and Betty Ann Lynn. A crowd of over 10
column4: 000 gathered to watch the celebrities paraded through downtown Sedalia on a donkey cart.In the American television movie The Day After (1983)
column5: aired by ABC
column6: Sedalia is destroyed when the Soviet Union attacks the Minuteman II Missile silos around the area. At the time of the movie's release
column7: 150 of the missiles were located in the Sedalia area in underground silos. They had been sited there since activation in early 1964 of the first Minuteman missiles under the control of the 351st Missile Wing located at Whiteman Air Force Base. The release of the movie led to a significant (if belated) increase in local community concern about the missiles. Concern remained high until all the missiles were dismantled between 1992 and 1997 as a result of the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty between the United States and Russia.

column1: A Sedalia Christmas is a multi-media play written in celebration of the Christmas traditions and celebrations of Sedalia from 1866 to 1969. It was written by  Rebecca Imhauser
column2: a Sedalia native. Local actors and actresses portray Sedalians and the events that shaped their lives. Historic photos are projected during the play to represent pivotal time frames
column3: with an emphasis on Christmas during the depression and World War Two eras. Sedalia's Christmas heritage is celebrated through favorite holiday and patriotic songs
column4: as well as choreographed dance numbers.  This musical is set in Sedalia. Imhauser
column5: a member of the Board of the Liberty Center Arts Association
column6: created the show in 2008
column7: basing it on her own knowledge
column8: extensive research of Sedalia's history and from her book All Along Ohio Street. The musical was first performed in the Liberty Center
column11: 2008. It was shown again in December 2009 with an improved script and a slightly altered cast.
